a.name: a
a.description: The anchor element creates hyperlinks to web pages, files, email addresses, locations in the same page, or anything else a URL can address. Content within each anchor should indicate the link's destination.
a.example: Visit Example Send Email Call Us

attributes.name: href
attributes.description: Specifies the URL or destination that the link points to. Can be a web address, email (mailto:), phone number (tel:), or anchor link (#section).

attributes.name: target
attributes.description: Defines where to open the linked document. Values: _blank (new tab), _self (same frame), _parent (parent frame), _top (full window).

attributes.name: download
attributes.description: Prompts the user to download the linked resource instead of navigating to it. The value suggests the filename.

attributes.name: rel
attributes.description: Specifies the relationship between the current document and the linked document. Common values: nofollow, noopener, noreferrer, external.

attributes.name: type
attributes.description: Hints at the linked resource's MIME type (e.g., text/html, application/pdf) to help browsers handle it appropriately.

attributes.name: hreflang
attributes.description: Indicates the language of the linked document using language codes (e.g., en, es, fr).

attributes.name: ping
attributes.description: Contains a space-separated list of URLs to be notified when the user follows the link (used for tracking).

attributes.name: referrerpolicy
attributes.description: Controls how much referrer information is sent when following the link. Values include: no-referrer, origin, strict-origin.

abbr.name: abbr
abbr.description: The abbreviation element represents an abbreviation or acronym. Use the title attribute to provide the full description of the abbreviation, which browsers and assistive technologies may present as a tooltip.
abbr.example: You can use CSS to style your pages.

attributes.name: title
attributes.description: Provides the full expansion or description of the abbreviation. Displayed as a tooltip when users hover over the element.

acronym.name: acronym
acronym.description: The acronym element was used to define acronyms. This element is deprecated in HTML5 and should not be used. Use the abbr element instead.

attributes.name: title
attributes.description: Provides the full expansion of the acronym. Shows as a tooltip on hover.

address.name: address
address.description: The address element indicates contact information for a person or organization. It can include any type of contact information, such as physical address, email, phone number, or social media links.
address.example:
Written by John Doe
Visit us at: 123 Main St, City, Country

area.name: area
area.description: The area element defines clickable regions within an image map. It is always nested inside a map element and works with the usemap attribute on img to create interactive image areas.

attributes.name: alt
attributes.description: Alternative text for the clickable area, important for accessibility and screen readers.

attributes.name: coords
attributes.description: Defines the coordinates of the clickable area. Format depends on shape: rect (x1,y1,x2,y2), circle (x,y,radius), poly (x1,y1,x2,y2,...).

attributes.name: shape
attributes.description: Specifies the shape of the clickable area. Values: rect (rectangle), circle, poly (polygon), default (entire image).

attributes.name: href
attributes.description: The URL that the area links to when clicked.

attributes.name: target
attributes.description: Specifies where to open the linked URL. Values: _blank, _self, _parent, _top.

attributes.name: download
attributes.description: Prompts to download the linked resource rather than navigate to it.

attributes.name: ping
attributes.description: URLs to notify when the area is clicked, used for tracking purposes.

attributes.name: rel
attributes.description: Relationship between current document and linked URL (e.g., nofollow, noopener).

attributes.name: referrerpolicy
attributes.description: Controls referrer information sent when the link is followed.

article.name: article
article.description: The article element represents a self-contained composition in a document, page, or site, which is intended to be independently distributable or reusable. Examples include blog posts, news articles, forum posts, or product cards.

aside.name: aside
aside.description: The aside element represents content that is tangentially related to the content around it. This could be sidebars, pull quotes, advertising, or groups of navigation elements. The content should be separable from the main content.

audio.name: audio
audio.description: The audio element embeds sound content in documents. It can contain one or more audio sources using the src attribute or source elements. The browser will choose the most suitable source.
audio.example:
<audio controls>
  <source src="audio.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
  <source src="audio.ogg" type="audio/ogg">
  Your browser does not support the audio element.
</audio>

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: Specifies the URL of the audio file to play.

attributes.name: controls
attributes.description: Displays the browser's default audio controls (play, pause, volume, etc.). Without this, audio is invisible.

attributes.name: autoplay
attributes.description: Makes the audio start playing automatically when the page loads. Note: Most browsers restrict autoplay without user interaction.

attributes.name: loop
attributes.description: Makes the audio repeat continuously from the beginning after it ends.

attributes.name: muted
attributes.description: Starts the audio with sound muted. Often required for autoplay to work in modern browsers.

attributes.name: preload
attributes.description: Hints how much audio to load before playing. Values: none (load nothing), metadata (load only metadata), auto (load entire file).

attributes.name: crossorigin
attributes.description: Configures CORS requests for audio from other domains. Values: anonymous, use-credentials.

b.name: b
b.description: The bold element draws attention to text without conveying extra importance. It is used for keywords, product names, or other text that should be stylistically offset from normal text without added emphasis.

base.name: base
base.description: The base element specifies the base URL and target for all relative URLs in a document. There can only be one base element per document, and it must be placed inside the head element.

attributes.name: href
attributes.description: Sets the base URL for all relative URLs in the document. All relative links will be resolved against this URL.

attributes.name: target
attributes.description: Sets the default target for all links in the document (e.g., _blank to open all links in new tabs).

bdi.name: bdi
bdi.description: The bidirectional isolate element isolates text that might be formatted in a different direction from surrounding text. This is useful when embedding user-generated content with unknown directionality.

bdo.name: bdo
bdo.description: The bidirectional text override element overrides the current text directionality, forcing text to be rendered in a specific direction regardless of the Unicode bidirectional algorithm.
bdo.example: This text will go right to left

attributes.name: dir
attributes.description: Specifies the text direction. Values: ltr (left-to-right) or rtl (right-to-left). Required attribute for bdo element.
attributes.example: <bdo dir="rtl">This text goes right to left</bdo>

big.name: big
big.description: The big element was used to make text one size larger. This element is deprecated in HTML5 and should not be used. Use CSS font-size property instead.

blockquote.name: blockquote
blockquote.description: The block quotation element indicates extended quotations from another source. The cite attribute can specify the source URL, and a citation can be provided using the cite element or footer element.
blockquote.example:
This is a quoted text from another source.

— Author Name

attributes.name: cite
attributes.description: Specifies the URL of the source from which the quotation is taken. This is not displayed but provides metadata about the quote's origin.

body.name: body
body.description: The body element represents the content of an HTML document. There can only be one body element per document, and it contains all the visible content like text, images, videos, links, etc.

br.name: br
br.description: The line break element produces a line break in text. It is useful for writing addresses or poems where line division is significant. Do not use br to create spacing between paragraphs; use CSS margin instead.

button.name: button
button.description: The button element represents a clickable button that can be used to submit forms or trigger actions with JavaScript. Unlike input type button, it can contain HTML content like images or formatted text.

attributes.name: type
attributes.description: Defines the button's behavior. Values: submit (submits form), reset (resets form), button (no default behavior, use with JavaScript).

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: The name of the button, which is sent with the form data when the button is used to submit a form.

attributes.name: value
attributes.description: The value associated with the button's name when submitted with form data.

attributes.name: disabled
attributes.description: Disables the button, making it unclickable and visually dimmed. Disabled buttons don't submit with forms.

attributes.name: form
attributes.description: Associates the button with a form element by its ID, even if the button is not nested inside the form.

attributes.name: formaction
attributes.description: Overrides the form's action attribute, specifying where to send form data when this button submits the form.

attributes.name: formmethod
attributes.description: Overrides the form's method attribute. Values: get, post. Defines how to send form data.

attributes.name: formtarget
attributes.description: Overrides the form's target attribute, specifying where to display the response after form submission.

attributes.name: formenctype
attributes.description: Overrides the form's enctype attribute, specifying how form data should be encoded before sending.

attributes.name: formnovalidate
attributes.description: Overrides the form's novalidate attribute, bypassing form validation when this button submits the form.

canvas.name: canvas
canvas.description: The canvas element provides a drawing surface for graphics via JavaScript. It can be used to draw shapes, images, text, or create animations and games. The actual rendering is done using the Canvas API or WebGL.
canvas.example:
<canvas id="myCanvas" width="200" height="100">
  Your browser does not support canvas.
</canvas>
<script>
  const canvas = document.getElementById('myCanvas');
  const ctx = canvas.getContext('2d');
  ctx.fillRect(20, 20, 150, 50);
</script>

attributes.name: width
attributes.description: The width of the canvas in pixels. Default is 300. Note: Set this via HTML attribute, not CSS, to avoid distortion.

attributes.name: height
attributes.description: The height of the canvas in pixels. Default is 150. Use the HTML attribute for proper rendering.

caption.name: caption
caption.description: The table caption element defines the title or caption for a table. It must be the first child of a table element and helps users quickly understand the purpose of the table.

center.name: center
center.description: The center element was used to center-align text and content. This element is deprecated in HTML5 and should not be used. Use CSS text-align center instead.

cite.name: cite
cite.description: The citation element marks the title of a creative work such as books, articles, essays, poems, songs, films, TV shows, games, sculptures, or paintings. It should not be used for citing people.
cite.example: My favorite book is The Great Gatsby by F. Scott Fitzgerald.

code.name: code
code.description: The code element displays text as computer code. Browsers typically render code text in a monospace font. For multiple lines of code, wrap the code element inside a pre element.
code.example:
Use the console.log() function to print output.

function hello() {
  console.log('Hello World');
}

col.name: col
col.description: The column element defines a column within a table and is used inside a colgroup element. It allows you to apply styling or attributes to entire columns rather than individual cells.

attributes.name: span
attributes.description: Specifies the number of consecutive columns this col element represents. Default is 1. Use to apply styles to multiple columns at once.

colgroup.name: colgroup
colgroup.description: The column group element defines a group of columns in a table. It must be placed after any caption elements and before any table content. It is used to apply common styling to multiple columns.

attributes.name: span
attributes.description: Specifies the number of consecutive columns in the group. Only used when colgroup has no col children. Default is 1.

data.name: data
data.description: The data element links content with a machine-readable translation. The value attribute provides the machine-readable value, while the element content shows the human-readable version.

attributes.name: value
attributes.description: Contains the machine-readable format of the element's content. Useful for JavaScript processing or microdata while displaying human-friendly text.

datalist.name: datalist
datalist.description: The datalist element contains a set of option elements representing predefined options for an input element. It provides an autocomplete feature, suggesting values as the user types.
datalist.example:
<label for="browser">Choose a browser:</label>
<input list="browsers" id="browser" name="browser">
<datalist id="browsers">
  <option value="Chrome">
  <option value="Firefox">
  <option value="Safari">
  <option value="Edge">
</datalist>

dd.name: dd
dd.description: The description details element provides the description, definition, or value for the preceding term (dt) in a description list (dl). Multiple dd elements can follow a single dt.
dd.example:
<dl>
  <dt>HTML</dt>
  <dd>HyperText Markup Language</dd>
  <dd>The standard markup language for web pages</dd>
</dl>

del.name: del
del.description: The deleted text element represents text that has been deleted from a document. Browsers typically render it with a strikethrough. Use the ins element to show inserted text.

attributes.name: cite
attributes.description: URL that explains or provides context for the deletion. Links to a document explaining why the text was removed.

attributes.name: datetime
attributes.description: The date and time when the deletion was made. Format: YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssTZD (e.g., 2024-01-15T14:30:00Z).

details.name: details
details.description: The details element creates a disclosure widget from which users can obtain additional information or controls. Only the summary is visible initially; clicking it reveals the hidden content.
details.example:
Click to expand

This is the hidden content that appears when expanded.

attributes.name: open
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that indicates whether the details are currently visible. When present, the widget is expanded by default.

dfn.name: dfn
dfn.description: The definition element marks the term being defined within the context of a definition phrase or sentence. The nearest ancestor paragraph, description list, or section is considered the definition.
dfn.example: HTML is the standard markup language for creating web pages.

dialog.name: dialog
dialog.description: The dialog element represents a dialog box or modal window. It can be shown using the show or showModal methods and closed with close. The open attribute makes it visible.
dialog.example: This is a dialog window

attributes.name: open
attributes.description: Boolean attribute indicating the dialog is active and available for interaction. Usually controlled via JavaScript methods show() or showModal().

dir.name: dir
dir.description: The directory element was used to create lists of directory titles. This element is deprecated in HTML5 and should not be used. Use ul instead.

div.name: div
div.description: The content division element is a generic container for flow content. It has no effect on content or layout until styled with CSS. Use it to group elements for styling purposes or as a JavaScript target.

dl.name: dl
dl.description: The description list element encloses a list of term-description pairs. Common uses include implementing a glossary, displaying metadata, or presenting key-value pairs.
dl.example:
<dl>
  <dt>Coffee</dt>
  <dd>A hot beverage made from roasted coffee beans</dd>
  <dt>Tea</dt>
  <dd>An aromatic beverage prepared by pouring hot water over tea leaves</dd>
</dl>

dt.name: dt
dt.description: The description term element specifies a term in a description list (dl). It must be followed by one or more dd elements that provide the description or definition of the term.

em.name: em
em.description: The emphasis element marks text that has stress emphasis. Screen readers will pronounce emphasized text with verbal stress. Browsers typically render it in italic, but you can change styling with CSS.

embed.name: embed
embed.description: The embed element embeds external content such as multimedia, plugins, or interactive applications. For most content types, consider using img, video, audio, or iframe instead.

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: The URL of the resource to embed. Required attribute for the embed element.

attributes.name: type
attributes.description: The MIME type of the embedded content (e.g., application/pdf, video/mp4). Helps the browser choose the right plugin.

attributes.name: width
attributes.description: The width of the embedded content in pixels or percentage.

attributes.name: height
attributes.description: The height of the embedded content in pixels or percentage.

fencedframe.name: fencedframe
fencedframe.description: The fenced frame element represents a nested browsing context similar to iframe, but with stronger privacy guarantees. It is experimental and designed for privacy-preserving APIs like Protected Audience.

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: The URL of the content to display in the fenced frame. Limited to specific privacy-preserving sources.

attributes.name: width
attributes.description: The width of the fenced frame in pixels.

attributes.name: height
attributes.description: The height of the fenced frame in pixels.

fieldset.name: fieldset
fieldset.description: The fieldset element groups related form controls and labels within a form. The legend element provides a caption for the fieldset, improving accessibility and organization.

attributes.name: disabled
attributes.description: Disables all form controls within the fieldset. Users cannot interact with disabled controls, and they won't be submitted.

attributes.name: form
attributes.description: Associates the fieldset with a form element by its ID, even if the fieldset is not nested inside that form.

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: The name of the fieldset, which can be used to reference it in JavaScript or for form organization.

figcaption.name: figcaption
figcaption.description: The figure caption element defines a caption or legend for a figure element. It can appear as the first or last child of the figure and describes the content within.

figure.name: figure
figure.description: The figure element represents self-contained content like illustrations, diagrams, photos, code listings, etc. It is usually referenced as a single unit from the main flow of the document.

font.name: font
font.description: The font element was used to define font size, color, and face for text. This element is deprecated in HTML5 and should not be used. Use CSS font properties instead.

attributes.name: color
attributes.description: Set the text color. Deprecated - use CSS color property instead.

attributes.name: size
attributes.description: Set the font size from 1 (smallest) to 7 (largest). Deprecated - use CSS font-size instead.

attributes.name: face
attributes.description: Specified the font family name. Deprecated - use CSS font-family instead.

footer.name: footer
footer.description: The footer element represents a footer for its nearest ancestor sectioning content or sectioning root. It typically contains information about the author, copyright, related links, or contact information.
footer.example:
© 2024 Company Name. All rights reserved.

Contact: info@example.com

form.name: form
form.description: The form element represents a document section containing interactive controls for submitting information. Forms can contain input fields, checkboxes, radio buttons, submit buttons, and more.

attributes.name: action
attributes.description: The URL where the form data will be sent when submitted. If omitted, the form submits to the current page.

attributes.name: method
attributes.description: The HTTP method for sending form data. Values: get (data in URL), post (data in request body). Default is get.

attributes.name: enctype
attributes.description: How form data should be encoded. Values: application/x-www-form-urlencoded (default), multipart/form-data (for file uploads), text/plain.

attributes.name: target
attributes.description: Where to display the response after submitting. Values: _self (same window), _blank (new window), _parent, _top.

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: The name of the form, used to reference it in JavaScript via document.forms.

attributes.name: autocomplete
attributes.description: Controls whether the browser should autocomplete form fields. Values: on (allow autocomplete), off (disable autocomplete).

attributes.name: novalidate
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that disables browser's built-in form validation when the form is submitted.

attributes.name: accept-charset
attributes.description: Specifies the character encodings that the server accepts. Default is the page's encoding.

frame.name: frame
frame.description: The frame element defined a particular area within a frameset where another HTML document could be displayed. This element is deprecated in HTML5 and should not be used.

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: URL of the document to display in the frame. Deprecated.

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: Name of the frame, used as a target for links. Deprecated.

attributes.name: scrolling
attributes.description: Whether to show scrollbars. Values: yes, no, auto. Deprecated.

attributes.name: frameborder
attributes.description: Whether to display a border around the frame. Values: 1 (yes), 0 (no). Deprecated.

frameset.name: frameset
frameset.description: The frameset element was used to contain frame elements and define the layout of frames. This element is deprecated in HTML5 and should not be used. Use CSS and iframe instead.

attributes.name: rows
attributes.description: Defines the height of each row in the frameset. Values can be pixels, percentages, or * for remaining space. Deprecated.

attributes.name: cols
attributes.description: Defines the width of each column in the frameset. Values can be pixels, percentages, or * for remaining space. Deprecated.

h1.name: h1
h1.description: The heading level 1 element represents the highest level section heading. Headings range from h1 (most important) to h6 (least important). Use only one h1 per page for SEO best practices.

head.name: head
head.description: The head element contains metadata about the document including its title, scripts, stylesheets, and other information that isn't displayed directly in the web page.

header.name: header
header.description: The header element represents introductory content, typically containing navigational aids, logo, search form, heading elements, or other introductory content. It can be used multiple times per page.

hgroup.name: hgroup
hgroup.description: The heading group element groups multiple heading elements (h1-h6) when a heading has multiple levels, such as subheadings, alternative titles, or taglines.

hr.name: hr
hr.description: The horizontal rule element represents a thematic break between paragraph-level elements. It is typically displayed as a horizontal line and indicates a shift of topic or scene.

html.name: html
html.description: The html element represents the root of an HTML document. All other elements must be descendants of this element. It should include the lang attribute to specify the language of the document.

attributes.name: lang
attributes.description: Specifies the primary language of the document using language codes (e.g., en for English, es for Spanish). Important for accessibility and SEO.

attributes.name: dir
attributes.description: Sets the text direction for the document. Values: ltr (left-to-right), rtl (right-to-left), auto.

i.name: i
i.description: The idiomatic text element represents text in an alternate voice or mood, such as technical terms, foreign language phrases, thoughts, or ship names. Browsers typically display it in italic.
i.example: The term et cetera is often abbreviated as etc.

iframe.name: iframe
iframe.description: The inline frame element embeds another HTML page into the current page. It creates a nested browsing context and is commonly used to embed videos, maps, or content from other domains.

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: The URL of the page to embed in the iframe.

attributes.name: srcdoc
attributes.description: Inline HTML content to display instead of loading from src. Overrides the src attribute.

attributes.name: width
attributes.description: The width of the iframe in pixels or percentage.

attributes.name: height
attributes.description: The height of the iframe in pixels or percentage.

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: A name for the iframe that can be used as a target for links or form submissions.

attributes.name: sandbox
attributes.description: Enables restrictions on the iframe content. Values: allow-scripts, allow-forms, allow-popups, allow-same-origin. Empty value applies all restrictions.

attributes.name: allow
attributes.description: Specifies a feature policy for the iframe (e.g., camera, microphone, geolocation). Format: feature-name source-list.

attributes.name: allowfullscreen
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that allows the iframe content to use the Fullscreen API.

attributes.name: loading
attributes.description: Controls when the iframe loads. Values: eager (load immediately), lazy (defer loading until near viewport).

attributes.name: referrerpolicy
attributes.description: Controls how much referrer information is sent when loading the iframe content.

img.name: img
img.description: The image element embeds an image into the document. The src attribute is required and specifies the image path. The alt attribute provides alternative text for accessibility and when images fail to load.

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: The URL or path to the image file. Required attribute.

attributes.name: alt
attributes.description: Alternative text describing the image. Essential for accessibility, SEO, and displays when image fails to load. Required for accessibility.

attributes.name: width
attributes.description: The intrinsic width of the image in pixels (without unit). Helps prevent layout shift during page load.

attributes.name: height
attributes.description: The intrinsic height of the image in pixels (without unit). Helps prevent layout shift during page load.

attributes.name: loading
attributes.description: Controls when to load the image. Values: eager (load immediately), lazy (defer loading until near viewport for performance).

attributes.name: srcset
attributes.description: List of image sources for different screen sizes/resolutions. Format: 'url size, url size'. Enables responsive images.

attributes.name: sizes
attributes.description: Media conditions indicating what image size to use from srcset. Format: '(condition) size, size'. Works with srcset.

attributes.name: crossorigin
attributes.description: Configures CORS requests for images from other domains. Values: anonymous, use-credentials.

attributes.name: usemap
attributes.description: Associates the image with a map element by its name (prefixed with #) to create clickable regions.

attributes.name: ismap
attributes.description: Boolean attribute indicating the image is a server-side image map. Only works if img is inside an anchor tag.

attributes.name: decoding
attributes.description: Hint for image decoding. Values: sync (decode synchronously), async (decode asynchronously), auto (browser decides).

attributes.name: referrerpolicy
attributes.description: Controls referrer information sent when fetching the image.

input.name: input
input.description: The input element creates interactive controls for forms to accept data from users. The type attribute determines the control's behavior, with over 20 different input types available.
input.example:
<input type="text" name="username" placeholder="Enter username">
<input type="email" name="email" required>
<input type="checkbox" name="agree" id="agree">
<input type="submit" value="Submit">

attributes.name: type
attributes.description: Defines the input control type. Values include: text, email, password, number, tel, url, search, checkbox, radio, file, date, time, color, submit, button, etc.

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: The name of the input field, used to identify the data when the form is submitted.

attributes.name: value
attributes.description: The initial value of the input. For buttons, it's the label. For checkboxes/radio, it's the value submitted when checked.

attributes.name: placeholder
attributes.description: Hint text displayed in the input when it's empty. Disappears when user starts typing.

attributes.name: required
attributes.description: Boolean attribute making the field mandatory. Form won't submit if this field is empty.

attributes.name: disabled
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that disables the input. User can't interact with it, and its value won't be submitted.

attributes.name: readonly
attributes.description: Boolean attribute making the input non-editable but still submittable and focusable. User can select but not change the value.

attributes.name: min
attributes.description: Minimum value for number, date, or time inputs. Used for validation.

attributes.name: max
attributes.description: Maximum value for number, date, or time inputs. Used for validation.

attributes.name: step
attributes.description: Increment value for number, range, date, or time inputs. For number type, defines precision (e.g., step='0.01' for decimals).

attributes.name: pattern
attributes.description: Regular expression pattern the input value must match for validation. Works with text, search, tel, url, email types.

attributes.name: autocomplete
attributes.description: Controls browser autofill. Values: on, off, or specific tokens like email, username, current-password, cc-number, etc.

attributes.name: autofocus
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that automatically focuses this input when the page loads. Only one element per page should have this.

attributes.name: multiple
attributes.description: Boolean attribute allowing multiple values. Used with email (multiple addresses) or file (multiple file selection) types.

attributes.name: accept
attributes.description: For file input, specifies acceptable file types. Format: .ext, audio/*, video/*, image/*, or MIME types.

attributes.name: checked
attributes.description: Boolean attribute for checkbox and radio inputs. When present, the input is selected by default.

ins.name: ins
ins.description: The inserted text element represents text that has been added to a document. Browsers typically underline inserted text. Use with del to show document changes or edits.

attributes.name: cite
attributes.description: URL that explains or provides context for the insertion. Links to a document explaining why the text was added.

attributes.name: datetime
attributes.description: The date and time when the insertion was made. Format: YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssTZD (e.g., 2024-01-15T14:30:00Z).

kbd.name: kbd
kbd.description: The keyboard input element represents textual user input from a keyboard, voice input, or any other text entry device. Browsers typically render it in a monospace font.

label.name: label
label.description: The label element represents a caption for a form control. Clicking the label activates the associated control. Associate labels using the for attribute matching the control's id.

attributes.name: for
attributes.description: The ID of the form control this label is associated with. Clicking the label will focus/activate that control. Improves accessibility and usability.

attributes.name: form
attributes.description: The ID of the form element this label belongs to. Allows label to be associated with a form even if not nested inside it.

legend.name: legend
legend.description: The legend element represents a caption for the content of its parent fieldset. It must be the first child of the fieldset and helps describe the purpose of grouped form controls.

li.name: li
li.description: The list item element represents an item in an ordered list (ol), unordered list (ul), or menu. In ordered lists, it typically has a number. In unordered lists, a bullet point.

attributes.name: value
attributes.description: For ordered lists only: sets the ordinal value of the list item. Subsequent items continue numbering from this value.

link.name: link
link.description: The link element specifies relationships between the current document and external resources. It is commonly used to link stylesheets, favicons, and other resources. It must be inside the head element.
link.example:
<head>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
  <link rel="icon" href="favicon.ico">
  <link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com">
</head>

attributes.name: href
attributes.description: The URL of the linked resource. Required for most link types.

attributes.name: rel
attributes.description: Defines the relationship between the current document and the linked resource. Values: stylesheet, icon, preconnect, prefetch, dns-prefetch, canonical, alternate, etc. Required attribute.

attributes.name: type
attributes.description: MIME type of the linked resource (e.g., text/css, image/x-icon). Helps browser understand the resource type.

attributes.name: media
attributes.description: Specifies which media/device the linked resource is optimized for. Uses media queries (e.g., screen, print, (max-width: 600px)).

attributes.name: as
attributes.description: For rel='preload' or 'prefetch', specifies the type of content being loaded. Values: script, style, image, font, document, etc.

attributes.name: crossorigin
attributes.description: Configures CORS for the resource. Values: anonymous, use-credentials.

attributes.name: integrity
attributes.description: Cryptographic hash to verify the resource hasn't been tampered with. Used for Subresource Integrity (SRI) security.

attributes.name: hreflang
attributes.description: Language of the linked resource using language codes (e.g., en, fr, es).

attributes.name: sizes
attributes.description: For rel='icon', specifies icon sizes. Format: 'widthxheight' (e.g., 16x16, 32x32) or 'any' for scalable icons.

main.name: main
main.description: The main element represents the dominant content of the document's body. Content should be unique to the document and exclude repeated content like sidebars, navigation, copyright, logos, and search forms.

map.name: map
map.description: The image map element defines an image map used with area elements to create clickable regions on an image. The name attribute associates the map with an image using the usemap attribute.

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: The name of the image map. Referenced by the img element's usemap attribute (with # prefix) to link the map to an image. Required attribute.

mark.name: mark
mark.description: The mark element represents text that is highlighted or marked for reference purposes due to its relevance in a particular context. Browsers typically render it with a yellow background.

marquee.name: marquee
marquee.description: The marquee element was used to create scrolling text or images. This element is deprecated and should not be used. Use CSS animations or JavaScript instead.
marquee.example: <marquee>This text scrolls from right to left</marquee>

attributes.name: behavior
attributes.description: Scrolling behavior. Values: scroll (move across and repeat), slide (move once and stop), alternate (bounce back and forth). Deprecated.

attributes.name: direction
attributes.description: Direction of scrolling. Values: left, right, up, down. Deprecated.

attributes.name: loop
attributes.description: Number of times to loop the scrolling. Value: number or 'infinite'. Deprecated.

attributes.name: scrollamount
attributes.description: Speed of scrolling in pixels per interval. Higher values = faster scrolling. Deprecated.

attributes.name: scrolldelay
attributes.description: Delay between each scroll movement in milliseconds. Deprecated.

menu.name: menu
menu.description: The menu element represents a semantic grouping of commands or menu items. It can be used for toolbars, context menus, or lists of form buttons. Often styled as an unordered list.

meta.name: meta
meta.description: The meta element represents metadata that cannot be represented by other meta-related elements like title, link, or style. It defines character encoding, viewport settings, descriptions, keywords, and more.
meta.example:
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <meta name="description" content="Page description">
  <meta name="keywords" content="HTML, CSS, JavaScript">
</head>

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: The type of metadata. Common values: description, keywords, author, viewport, robots, theme-color. Pairs with content attribute.

attributes.name: content
attributes.description: The value of the metadata specified by name or http-equiv. Required when using name or http-equiv attributes.

attributes.name: charset
attributes.description: Declares the character encoding for the document. Almost always UTF-8. Should be in first 1024 bytes of document.

attributes.name: http-equiv
attributes.description: Provides an HTTP header for the information in content. Values: refresh, content-type, default-style, content-security-policy.

meter.name: meter
meter.description: The meter element represents a scalar measurement within a known range, such as disk usage, vote counts, or relevance of search results. It should not be used for progress indicators; use progress instead.
meter.example: <label>Disk usage: <meter value="6" min="0" max="10">6 out of 10</meter></label>

attributes.name: value
attributes.description: The current numeric value. Must be between min and max. Required attribute.

attributes.name: min
attributes.description: The minimum value of the range. Default is 0.

attributes.name: max
attributes.description: The maximum value of the range. Default is 1.

attributes.name: low
attributes.description: The upper bound of the low range. Values below this are considered low. Must be greater than min.

attributes.name: high
attributes.description: The lower bound of the high range. Values above this are considered high. Must be less than max.

attributes.name: optimum
attributes.description: The optimal numeric value. Indicates which range is preferred. Browser uses this to color-code the meter.
attributes.example: <meter value="5" min="0" low="3" optimum="5" high="7" max="10"></meter>

attributes.name: form
attributes.description: Associates the meter with a form element by its ID.

nav.name: nav
nav.description: The navigation element represents a section of a page containing navigation links, either within the current document or to other documents. Not all link groups need to be in a nav element.

nobr.name: nobr
nobr.description: The no break element prevented line breaks in text, forcing text to display on a single line. This element is deprecated and should not be used. Use CSS white-space nowrap instead.
nobr.example: <nobr>This text will not break across lines</nobr>

noembed.name: noembed
noembed.description: The noembed element provided fallback content for browsers that didn't support the embed element. This element is deprecated and obsolete. Modern browsers all support embed.
noembed.example:
<embed src="video.swf">
<noembed>Your browser does not support embedded content.</noembed>

noframes.name: noframes
noframes.description: The noframes element provided content for browsers that didn't support frames. This element is deprecated along with frame and frameset and should not be used.
noframes.example:
<frameset>
  <frame src="frame.html">
  <noframes>Your browser does not support frames.</noframes>
</frameset>

noscript.name: noscript
noscript.description: The noscript element defines content to be displayed when JavaScript is disabled in the user's browser or if the browser doesn't support scripts. It provides a fallback for script-dependent content.
noscript.example: Please enable JavaScript to use this website.

object.name: object
object.description: The object element embeds external resources such as images, videos, PDFs, or other documents. It can also embed plugins. Use param elements inside to pass parameters to the embedded content.

attributes.name: data
attributes.description: The URL of the resource to embed. Required for most uses.

attributes.name: type
attributes.description: The MIME type of the embedded resource (e.g., application/pdf, video/mp4, image/svg+xml). Helps browser render it correctly.

attributes.name: width
attributes.description: The width of the object in pixels or percentage.

attributes.name: height
attributes.description: The height of the object in pixels or percentage.

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: Name of the embedded content, which can be used as a target for links or forms.

attributes.name: usemap
attributes.description: Associates the object with an image map by its name (prefixed with #).

attributes.name: form
attributes.description: Associates the object with a form element by its ID.

ol.name: ol
ol.description: The ordered list element represents a list of items with a meaningful order. Items are typically displayed with numbering, which can be numerical, alphabetical, or Roman numerals.

attributes.name: type
attributes.description: The numbering type. Values: 1 (numbers, default), a (lowercase letters), A (uppercase letters), i (lowercase roman), I (uppercase roman).

attributes.name: start
attributes.description: The starting number for the list. For example, start='5' begins numbering at 5. Works with all type values.

attributes.name: reversed
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that reverses the numbering order (counts down instead of up).

optgroup.name: optgroup
optgroup.description: The option group element creates a grouping of options within a select element. The label attribute provides a name for the group, which is displayed but not selectable.

attributes.name: label
attributes.description: The name of the option group, displayed as a heading above the grouped options. Required attribute.

attributes.name: disabled
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that disables all options in the group, making them unselectable.

option.name: option
option.description: The option element defines an option in a select, datalist, or optgroup element. Each option represents a choice that users can select. The selected attribute marks the default choice.

attributes.name: value
attributes.description: The value submitted with the form when this option is selected. If omitted, the text content is used as the value.

attributes.name: selected
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that marks this option as selected by default when the page loads.

attributes.name: disabled
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that makes this option unselectable and visually dimmed.

attributes.name: label
attributes.description: A shorter label for the option. If present, it's displayed instead of the text content.

output.name: output
output.description: The output element represents the result of a calculation or user action. It is typically used with form elements and can be updated dynamically with JavaScript to show computed values.
output.example:
<form oninput="result.value=parseInt(a.value)+parseInt(b.value)">
  <input type="number" id="a" value="0"> +
  <input type="number" id="b" value="0"> =
  <output name="result" for="a b">0</output>
</form>

attributes.name: for
attributes.description: Space-separated list of IDs of elements that contributed to the calculation. Establishes relationships between inputs and output.

attributes.name: form
attributes.description: Associates the output with a form element by its ID, even if not nested inside the form.

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: The name of the output element, which can be used to reference it in JavaScript or include it in form data.

p.name: p
p.description: The paragraph element represents a paragraph of text. Paragraphs are block-level elements and are typically displayed with space before and after. They are one of the most commonly used HTML elements.
p.example: This is a paragraph of text. It can contain multiple sentences and will automatically wrap to fit the container width.

param.name: param
param.description: The parameter element defines parameters for an object element. It was used to pass name-value pairs to plugins. This element is deprecated in modern HTML.

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: The name of the parameter being passed to the embedded object. Deprecated.

attributes.name: value
attributes.description: The value of the parameter. Deprecated.

picture.name: picture
picture.description: The picture element contains zero or more source elements and one img element to offer alternative versions of an image for different display scenarios, such as responsive images or different formats.

plaintext.name: plaintext
plaintext.description: The plaintext element rendered everything after it as plain text without parsing HTML. This element is deprecated and obsolete. Use pre with code or escape HTML entities instead.
plaintext.example: <p>This will be displayed as plain text, not HTML</p>

pre.name: pre
pre.description: The preformatted text element displays text exactly as written in the HTML, preserving spaces, line breaks, and indentation. Text is typically rendered in a monospace font.

progress.name: progress
progress.description: The progress element displays an indicator showing the completion progress of a task, such as file uploads or form completions. Use the value and max attributes to set the current and maximum values.

attributes.name: value
attributes.description: The current progress value. Must be between 0 and max. If omitted, the progress bar is indeterminate (animated but no specific value).

attributes.name: max
attributes.description: The maximum value, representing 100% completion. Default is 1. Must be greater than 0.

q.name: q
q.description: The inline quotation element indicates short quotations that don't require paragraph breaks. Browsers automatically insert quotation marks around the text. The cite attribute can specify the source URL.
q.example: According to the manual, always save your work.

attributes.name: cite
attributes.description: URL of the source from which the quotation is taken. Provides metadata but is not displayed visually.

rb.name: rb
rb.description: The ruby base element was used to delimit the base text component of a ruby annotation. This element is deprecated. Use ruby text directly without wrapping in rb.

rp.name: rp
rp.description: The ruby parenthesis element provides fallback parentheses for browsers that don't support ruby annotations. The content is shown only in browsers that don't support ruby.

rt.name: rt
rt.description: The ruby text element specifies the pronunciation or meaning of characters in a ruby annotation. It is used to show pronunciation guides for East Asian typography.

rtc.name: rtc
rtc.description: The ruby text container element was used to contain semantic annotations of characters in a ruby annotation. This element is deprecated and not widely supported.

ruby.name: ruby
ruby.description: The ruby element represents small annotations typically used above or beside East Asian characters to show pronunciation or meaning. It contains base text and ruby text (rt) elements.

s.name: s
s.description: The strikethrough element renders text with a strikethrough line through it, indicating content that is no longer accurate or relevant. Use del if you need to indicate deleted content instead.

samp.name: samp
samp.description: The sample output element represents sample or quoted output from a computer program. Browsers typically render it in a monospace font to distinguish it from regular text.

script.name: script
script.description: The script element embeds or references executable code, typically JavaScript. It can contain inline code or reference an external file using the src attribute. Scripts can be deferred or made async.

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: URL of an external script file. When present, the element's content is ignored.

attributes.name: type
attributes.description: MIME type of the script. Default is text/javascript. Use 'module' for ES6 modules. Other types like 'application/json' for data.

attributes.name: async
attributes.description: Boolean attribute for external scripts. Downloads script in parallel and executes as soon as available, without blocking HTML parsing.

attributes.name: defer
attributes.description: Boolean attribute for external scripts. Downloads in parallel but delays execution until HTML parsing is complete. Maintains script order.

attributes.name: crossorigin
attributes.description: Configures CORS for external scripts. Values: anonymous, use-credentials.

attributes.name: integrity
attributes.description: Cryptographic hash for Subresource Integrity (SRI) verification. Ensures the script hasn't been tampered with.

attributes.name: nomodule
attributes.description: Boolean attribute. Script executes only in browsers that don't support ES6 modules. Used for fallback scripts.

attributes.name: referrerpolicy
attributes.description: Controls referrer information sent when fetching the script.

search.name: search
search.description: The search element represents a section containing search functionality. It semantically identifies search features on a page and can contain search forms, filters, or search results.
search.example:
<search>
  <form action="/search" method="get">
    <input type="search" name="q" placeholder="Search...">
    <button type="submit">Search</button>
  </form>
</search>

section.name: section
section.description: The section element represents a generic standalone section of a document that doesn't have a more specific semantic element. Sections should typically have a heading as their first child.

select.name: select
select.description: The select element creates a dropdown list of options. Users can choose one or multiple options depending on the multiple attribute. Options are defined using option elements.
select.example:
<label for="country">Choose a country:</label>
<select id="country" name="country">
  <option value="us">United States</option>
  <option value="ca">Canada</option>
  <option value="uk">United Kingdom</option>
</select>

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: The name of the select control, used to identify it when the form is submitted.

attributes.name: multiple
attributes.description: Boolean attribute allowing selection of multiple options. Users can select multiple items with Ctrl/Cmd+click.

attributes.name: required
attributes.description: Boolean attribute making selection mandatory. Form won't submit without a selection.

attributes.name: disabled
attributes.description: Boolean attribute disabling the entire select control. User can't interact with it, and its value won't be submitted.

attributes.name: size
attributes.description: Number of visible options. If greater than 1 or multiple is set, displays as a scrollable list box instead of dropdown.

attributes.name: autofocus
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that automatically focuses this select when the page loads.

attributes.name: form
attributes.description: Associates the select with a form element by its ID, even if not nested inside the form.

selectedcontent.name: selectedcontent
selectedcontent.description: The selected content element is an experimental feature that represents the selected content in a page. This is part of the CSS Custom Highlight API and is not yet widely supported.

slot.name: slot
slot.description: The slot element is a placeholder inside a web component that you can fill with your own markup. It enables creating flexible, reusable components by allowing users to customize parts of the component.

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: The name of the slot. Used to identify which content goes into which slot when using the component. Unnamed slots are default slots.

small.name: small
small.description: The small element represents side comments and small print, such as copyright and legal text. It renders text in a smaller font size, but should be used for semantic purposes, not just styling.
small.example:
Product price: $99.99

© 2024 Company Name. All rights reserved.

source.name: source
source.description: The source element specifies multiple media resources for picture, audio, or video elements. The browser chooses the most suitable source based on format support, screen size, or other factors.
source.example:
<video controls>
  <source src="video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  <source src="video.webm" type="video/webm">
  Your browser doesn't support video.
</video>

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: URL of the media resource. Required for audio and video. For picture, use srcset instead.

attributes.name: type
attributes.description: MIME type of the media resource (e.g., video/mp4, audio/ogg, image/webp). Helps browser select compatible format without downloading.

attributes.name: srcset
attributes.description: For picture element: list of image sources with their widths or pixel densities. Format: 'url width, url width' or 'url 1x, url 2x'.

attributes.name: sizes
attributes.description: For picture element: media conditions describing image display size. Works with srcset to choose appropriate image.

attributes.name: media
attributes.description: For picture element: media query determining when this source should be used (e.g., '(min-width: 600px)').

attributes.name: width
attributes.description: For picture element: intrinsic width of the image in pixels.

attributes.name: height
attributes.description: For picture element: intrinsic height of the image in pixels.

span.name: span
span.description: The span element is a generic inline container for phrasing content. It has no semantic meaning and is used to group elements for styling with CSS or as a target for JavaScript.
span.example: This is highlighted text in a paragraph.

strike.name: strike
strike.description: The strike element rendered text with a strikethrough. This element is deprecated in HTML5 and should not be used. Use s or del with CSS instead.

strong.name: strong
strong.description: The strong element indicates strong importance, seriousness, or urgency for its contents. Browsers typically render it in bold, but the emphasis is semantic, not just visual.

style.name: style
style.description: The style element contains CSS style information for a document. It is typically placed in the head section but can also be used in the body with certain restrictions.
style.example:
<style>
  body {
    font-family: Arial, sans-serif;
    color: #333;
  }
  h1 {
    color: blue;
  }
</style>

attributes.name: media
attributes.description: Specifies which media/device the styles are optimized for. Uses media queries (e.g., screen, print, (max-width: 600px)).

attributes.name: type
attributes.description: MIME type of the style language. Default is text/css. Usually omitted since CSS is the default.

sub.name: sub
sub.description: The subscript element renders text as subscript, appearing half a character below the normal line. It is used for mathematical formulas, chemical formulas, or footnote references.

summary.name: summary
summary.description: The summary element specifies a visible heading for a details element. Clicking the summary toggles the visibility of the details content. If omitted, the browser provides a default summary.
summary.example:
Click to see more

This is the hidden content revealed by clicking the summary.

sup.name: sup
sup.description: The superscript element renders text as superscript, appearing half a character above the normal line. It is used for exponents, ordinal indicators, or mathematical notation.

table.name: table
table.description: The table element represents tabular data displayed in rows and columns. Tables should be used for data, not for layout. Use CSS Grid or Flexbox for layouts instead.

tbody.name: tbody
tbody.description: The table body element groups the body content of a table. It is used with thead and tfoot to semantically organize table sections and enable independent scrolling or styling.

td.name: td
td.description: The table data cell element defines a cell in a table that contains data. Cells can span multiple rows or columns using rowspan and colspan attributes.

attributes.name: colspan
attributes.description: Number of columns the cell should span. Default is 1. Useful for creating cells that extend across multiple columns.

attributes.name: rowspan
attributes.description: Number of rows the cell should span. Default is 1. Useful for creating cells that extend across multiple rows.

attributes.name: headers
attributes.description: Space-separated list of header cell IDs that this cell is associated with. Improves table accessibility for screen readers.

template.name: template
template.description: The template element holds HTML that is not rendered when the page loads but can be instantiated later using JavaScript. It is useful for creating reusable content structures.

textarea.name: textarea
textarea.description: The textarea element creates a multi-line plain text editing control. It is useful for forms where users need to enter substantial amounts of text, such as comments or messages.
textarea.example:
<label for="message">Message:</label>
<textarea id="message" name="message" rows="4" cols="50" placeholder="Enter your message..."></textarea>

attributes.name: name
attributes.description: The name of the textarea control, used to identify it when the form is submitted.

attributes.name: rows
attributes.description: Number of visible text lines. Controls the default height of the textarea.

attributes.name: cols
attributes.description: Number of visible character widths. Controls the default width of the textarea.

attributes.name: placeholder
attributes.description: Hint text displayed when the textarea is empty. Disappears when user starts typing.

attributes.name: required
attributes.description: Boolean attribute making the textarea mandatory. Form won't submit if this field is empty.

attributes.name: disabled
attributes.description: Boolean attribute disabling the textarea. User can't interact with it, and its value won't be submitted.

attributes.name: readonly
attributes.description: Boolean attribute making the textarea non-editable but still submittable and focusable.

attributes.name: maxlength
attributes.description: Maximum number of characters allowed. Browser prevents entering more characters.

attributes.name: minlength
attributes.description: Minimum number of characters required for validation.

attributes.name: wrap
attributes.description: How text wraps when submitted. Values: soft (no wrapping in submitted data, default), hard (line breaks included in submitted data, requires cols).

attributes.name: autocomplete
attributes.description: Controls browser autofill. Values: on, off.

attributes.name: autofocus
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that automatically focuses this textarea when the page loads.

attributes.name: form
attributes.description: Associates the textarea with a form element by its ID, even if not nested inside the form.

tfoot.name: tfoot
tfoot.description: The table foot element groups footer content in a table. It typically contains summary rows such as totals or averages. It must appear after any caption, colgroup, thead, or tbody elements.

th.name: th
th.description: The table header cell element defines a cell as a header for a group of table cells. Header cells are typically bold and centered and provide context for data cells. Use the scope attribute for accessibility.

attributes.name: colspan
attributes.description: Number of columns the header cell should span. Default is 1.

attributes.name: rowspan
attributes.description: Number of rows the header cell should span. Default is 1.

attributes.name: scope
attributes.description: Defines which cells this header applies to. Values: row (header for row), col (header for column), rowgroup, colgroup. Important for accessibility.

attributes.name: headers
attributes.description: Space-separated list of other header cell IDs this cell is associated with. For complex tables with multiple header levels.

attributes.name: abbr
attributes.description: Abbreviated version of the header text. Screen readers may use this for a shorter description.

thead.name: thead
thead.description: The table head element groups header content in a table. It typically contains rows of column headers and must appear after any caption and colgroup elements.

time.name: time
time.description: The time element represents a specific time or time range. The datetime attribute provides a machine-readable format while the element content shows the human-readable version.
time.example: The concert starts at 8:00 PM on December 31, 2024.

attributes.name: datetime
attributes.description: Machine-readable date/time in ISO 8601 format. Examples: 2024-01-15 (date), 14:30 (time), 2024-01-15T14:30:00Z (full datetime). Required if content is not parseable.

title.name: title
title.description: The title element defines the document's title shown in the browser's title bar or page tab. It is required in all HTML documents and must be placed inside the head element.

tr.name: tr
tr.description: The table row element defines a row of cells in a table. Each row contains one or more th or td elements. Rows are grouped within thead, tbody, or tfoot sections.

track.name: track
track.description: The track element specifies timed text tracks for video and audio elements. It is used to add subtitles, captions, descriptions, chapters, or metadata to media elements.
track.example:
<video controls>
  <source src="video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  <track src="subtitles_en.vtt" kind="subtitles" srclang="en" label="English">
  <track src="subtitles_es.vtt" kind="subtitles" srclang="es" label="Spanish">
</video>

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: URL of the track file (usually .vtt format). Required attribute.

attributes.name: kind
attributes.description: Type of text track. Values: subtitles (translation for dialogue), captions (dialogue + sounds), descriptions (visual descriptions), chapters (chapter titles), metadata (hidden data for scripts).

attributes.name: srclang
attributes.description: Language of the track using language codes (e.g., en, es, fr). Required if kind is subtitles.

attributes.name: label
attributes.description: User-visible title for the track shown in the media player's track selection menu (e.g., 'English Subtitles').

attributes.name: default
attributes.description: Boolean attribute indicating this track should be enabled by default unless user preferences indicate otherwise.

tt.name: tt
tt.description: The teletype text element was used to display text in a monospace font, representing computer terminal output. This element is deprecated in HTML5 and should not be used. Use code, kbd, or samp instead.

u.name: u
u.description: The unarticulated annotation element renders text with an underline, representing text with a non-textual annotation such as Chinese proper name marks or spelling errors. For emphasis, use em instead.

ul.name: ul
ul.description: The unordered list element represents a list of items where the order doesn't matter. Items are typically displayed with bullet points. Use ol when the order is significant.

var.name: var
var.description: The variable element represents a variable in mathematical expressions or programming contexts. Browsers typically render it in italic to distinguish it from regular text.

video.name: video
video.description: The video element embeds video content in a document. It can contain multiple sources for format compatibility and provides a fallback message for unsupported browsers. Controls can be added for playback.
video.example:
<video width="640" height="360" controls>
  <source src="video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  <source src="video.webm" type="video/webm">
  Your browser doesn't support video playback.
</video>

attributes.name: src
attributes.description: The URL of the video file to play. Can be omitted if using source elements instead.

attributes.name: controls
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that displays the browser's default video controls (play, pause, volume, fullscreen, etc.).

attributes.name: autoplay
attributes.description: Makes the video start playing automatically when the page loads. Most browsers require muted attribute for autoplay to work.

attributes.name: loop
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that makes the video repeat continuously from the beginning after it ends.

attributes.name: muted
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that starts the video with sound muted. Often required for autoplay to work in modern browsers.

attributes.name: preload
attributes.description: Hints how much video to load before playing. Values: none (load nothing), metadata (load only metadata like duration), auto (load entire file).

attributes.name: poster
attributes.description: URL of an image to display as the video thumbnail before the video plays. Shows while video is loading or before user clicks play.

attributes.name: width
attributes.description: The display width of the video in pixels. Should match video aspect ratio with height.

attributes.name: height
attributes.description: The display height of the video in pixels. Should match video aspect ratio with width.

attributes.name: crossorigin
attributes.description: Configures CORS requests for video from other domains. Values: anonymous, use-credentials.

attributes.name: playsinline
attributes.description: Boolean attribute that allows video to play inline on mobile devices instead of fullscreen. Important for iOS devices.

wbr.name: wbr
wbr.description: The word break opportunity element represents a position within text where the browser may optionally break a line, even though its line-breaking rules would not otherwise create a break at that location.

xmp.name: xmp
xmp.description: The example element was used to display preformatted text without parsing HTML tags. This element is deprecated and obsolete. Use pre with escaped HTML entities instead.
